The film is divided in three chapters which Barve said was also a metaphor for the 'journey of India, as we see it today.'

node_2: first half hour of the film
edge: The first half hour of the film is in the 'universe of Dharap's stories.'

The film's locations, such as the Mutha River in the Onkareshwar area and a doppelganger set of an old Pune city, were recreated for shooting. The director, Barve, stated that these locations, with their stuffy air and lonely rainy atmosphere, are central to the film.
For creating the set of the small town around the temple, the Mutha River in the Onkareshwar area was taken as a reference. It took three weeks to complete this process.
The set of the small town around the temple was created during the filming process.

node_2: typical attire worn by konkanasth brahmans in maharashtra
edge: During the filming process, Sohum Shah wore the typical attire worn by Konkanasth Brahmans in Maharashtra.

node_2: gandhi and mitesh turned it into one person's story
edge: Barve's initial idea was to tell three different stories of Tummbad village in the film, but Gandhi and Mitesh turned it into one person's story.
The myth of Hastar was the last addition to the story, serving as a backstory.
The film Tumbbad is set in the village of Tumbbad, located in Maharashtra.
In the film Tumbbad, Sohum Shah wore the traditional attire worn by Konkanasth Brahmans in Maharashtra.
Konkanasth Brahmans are a community belonging to the Maharashtra region in India.
Some scenes from the film Tumbbad were also shot in Mahabaleshwar and the Tumbbad village.
The visual effects for the film Tumbbad were produced by Sean Wheelan's team at Filmgate Films, who were also co-producers.
Pankaj Kumar, the director of photography for Tumbbad, had previously shot Barve's short film Manjha in 2006.

The entire shooting schedule for the film Tumbbad revolved around lighting, and it was decided to shoot the village only during the monsoon with its constant rain, as the filmmakers wanted a feeling of 'wetness at all times'.
The filming for Tummbad was done without any sunlight on Red Camera in digital format.

contrast between waiting for hours for cloud cover in the context and using contemporary lighting techniques. Cloud cover is a natural element, while modern lighting techniques represent technology and human intervention.
spatial relationship between Maharashtra and Satara district. Maharashtra is a larger geographical location that encompasses Satara district.

use of different colours to create a specific atmosphere in different scenes, including scenes inside the womb.
alternative methods used by the production team to avoid using modern-day lighting techniques in a period film, which can affect the overall atmosphere of the scenes.
use of contact lenses by an actor as part of the character's appearance.

The interiors of the cave were shot at Purandare Wada near Pune to make it look old and 'consumed by earth'.
The crew spread moss all over the site for an entire market that was created at Satara but not used very often in the film.
The post-production took two-and-a-half years to complete after Kaza asked Prasad to write the dialogues again based on her rearrangement of the grandmother's tree scene during editing.
The initial runtime was close to 200 minutes which was edited down to 100 minutes.
The film's climax inside the womb was shot with only one source of light - an oil lamp.
